CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: However , the rms roughness is somewhat reduced to from 0.47 to 0.43 nm with thermal treatment , being favorable for charge separation and transport. This can reasonably explain the enhanced efficiency via the postannealing effect. Note that , in stark contrast to PCDTBT : PC71BM system in which thermal annealing reduced the photovoltaic parameters ( FF , J SC , and V OC ) , 22 the performance of all PCDSeBT - based devices for this study is considerably improved as a result of thermal treatment. We can conclude that the formation of crystalline nanoscale domains would be slightly induced in PCDSeBT : PC71BM with a thermal treatment in consequence of the ordered crystalline nature of the PCDSeBT on annealing as supported by the XRD results above as well as the large quinoidal character in the polymer backbone as the inclusion of selenophene. 23 The AFM of the annealed film gives an evidence for slightly nanofibril - like organization ( see Figure 5b ). The hole and electron mobilities of PCDSeBT : PC71BM ( 1 : 4 w / w ) blends were measured using the space - charge - limited current ( SCLC ) method and the J-V characteristics were plotted in Figure 6. The hole mobility ( μ hole = 4.68 × 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s ) obtained with the thermally annealed film is one order higher than that without post annealing ( μ hole = 4.02 × 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s ) , whereas in the both cases , the electron mobilities ( μ electron ) are similar ( 1.24 × 10^-3 and 5.58 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s ) for as-cast and annealed films , respectively , yielding a smaller difference between the mobility ratio for the annealed film. The higher mobilities and more balanced charge transport should definitely favor the charge transportation in the blend film and lead to high solar cell performance , supporting the b e n e fi c i a l e ff e c t o f t h e t h e r m a l a n n e a l i n g o n PCDSeBT : PC71BM cells . In conclusion , diselenienylbenzothiadiazole ( DSeBT ) units have successfully been incorporated into a D-A polymer backbone by Suzuki polymerization with 2,7-carbazole comonomer , affording a poly(2,7-carbazole-alt-diselenienylbenzothiadiazole) ( PCDSeBT ) ; This design motif is that replacement of thiophenes to selenophene units in PCDTBT that acts as a superior p - type photoactive material for PSCs , induces a lower bandgap ( 1.70 eV ) than that of PCDTBT ( 1.85 eV ) , while the ideal HOMO energy level ( -5.40 eV ) is still maintained.

Let's think step by step.

1. The first material name is "rms roughness," which is a measurement of the roughness of a surface.
2. The second material name is "PCDTBT," which is a type of polymer used in organic electronics.
3. The third material name is "PC71BM," which is a fullerene derivative used in organic electronics.
4. The fourth material name is "PCDSeBT," which is a type of polymer that is being studied in the paragraph. It is a derivative of PCDTBT with selenophene units replacing thiophene units.
5. The fifth material name is "carbazole," which is a heterocyclic organic compound used as a building block in the synthesis of PCDSeBT.
6. The sixth material name is "diselenienylbenzothiadiazole (DSeBT)," which is a unit that has been incorporated into the polymer backbone of PCDSeBT.
7. The seventh material name is "fullerene," which is a type of allotrope of carbon mentioned in relation to PC71BM.

Note: I am not completely sure about the identification of "the ideal HOMO energy level (-5.40 eV)" as a material name, but I included it as it is a property of the material PCDSeBT.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

1. The first material name is "rms roughness," which is a measurement of the roughness of a surface.
2. The second material name is "PCDTBT," which is a type of polymer used in organic electronics.
3. The third material name is "PC71BM," which is a fullerene derivative used in organic electronics.
4. The fourth material name is "PCDSeBT," which is a type of polymer that is being studied in the paragraph. It is a derivative of PCDTBT with selenophene units replacing thiophene units.
5. The fifth material name is "carbazole," which is a heterocyclic organic compound used as a building block in the synthesis of PCDSeBT.
6. The sixth material name is "diselenienylbenzothiadiazole (DSeBT)," which is a unit that has been incorporated into the polymer backbone of PCDSeBT.

Note: I have removed the potential material name "the ideal HOMO energy level (-5.40 eV)" as it is a property of the material PCDSeBT, not the material name itself.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| rms roughness |
| PCDTBT |
| PC71BM |
| PCDSeBT |
| carbazole |
| diselenienylbenzothiadiazole (DSeBT) |

PV.content:
Please identify the Values (number + unit) of material properties in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: However , the rms roughness is somewhat reduced to from 0.47 to 0.43 nm with thermal treatment , being favorable for charge separation and transport. This can reasonably explain the enhanced efficiency via the postannealing effect. Note that , in stark contrast to PCDTBT : PC71BM system in which thermal annealing reduced the photovoltaic parameters ( FF , J SC , and V OC ) , 22 the performance of all PCDSeBT - based devices for this study is considerably improved as a result of thermal treatment. We can conclude that the formation of crystalline nanoscale domains would be slightly induced in PCDSeBT : PC71BM with a thermal treatment in consequence of the ordered crystalline nature of the PCDSeBT on annealing as supported by the XRD results above as well as the large quinoidal character in the polymer backbone as the inclusion of selenophene. 23 The AFM of the annealed film gives an evidence for slightly nanofibril - like organization ( see Figure 5b ). The hole and electron mobilities of PCDSeBT : PC71BM ( 1 : 4 w / w ) blends were measured using the space - charge - limited current ( SCLC ) method and the J-V characteristics were plotted in Figure 6. The hole mobility ( μ hole = 4.68 × 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s ) obtained with the thermally annealed film is one order higher than that without post annealing ( μ hole = 4.02 × 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s ) , whereas in the both cases , the electron mobilities ( μ electron ) are similar ( 1.24 × 10^-3 and 5.58 × 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s ) for as-cast and annealed films , respectively , yielding a smaller difference between the mobility ratio for the annealed film. The higher mobilities and more balanced charge transport should definitely favor the charge transportation in the blend film and lead to high solar cell performance , supporting the b e n e fi c i a l e ff e c t o f t h e t h e r m a l a n n e a l i n g o n PCDSeBT : PC71BM cells . In conclusion , diselenienylbenzothiadiazole ( DSeBT ) units have successfully been incorporated into a D-A polymer backbone by Suzuki polymerization with 2,7-carbazole comonomer , affording a poly(2,7-carbazole-alt-diselenienylbenzothiadiazole) ( PCDSeBT ) ; This design motif is that replacement of thiophenes to selenophene units in PCDTBT that acts as a superior p - type photoactive material for PSCs , induces a lower bandgap ( 1.70 eV ) than that of PCDTBT ( 1.85 eV ) , while the ideal HOMO energy level ( -5.40 eV ) is still maintained.

Let's think step by step.

1. RMS roughness: Before thermal treatment - 0.47 nm, After thermal treatment - 0.43 nm.
2. Hole mobility: Without post-annealing - 4.02 x 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s, With thermally annealed film - 4.68 x 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s.
3. Electron mobility: As-cast film - 1.24 x 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s, Annealed film - 5.58 x 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s.
4. Bandgap: PCDTBT - 1.85 eV, PCDSeBT - 1.70 eV.
5. HOMO energy level: PCDSeBT - -5.40 eV.

These values are related to the material properties of the organic semiconductors used in the study. The roughness values are important for understanding the surface properties of the materials, while the mobility values are crucial for determining the charge transport properties. The bandgap and HOMO energy level values are essential for understanding the optical and electronic properties of the materials.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Value of Material Property.

1. RMS roughness: 0.47 nm (before thermal treatment), 0.43 nm (after thermal treatment).
2. Hole mobility: 4.02 x 10^-6 cm^2 / V°s (without post-annealing), 4.68 x 10^-5 cm^2 / V°s (with thermally annealed film).
3. Electron mobility: 1.24 x 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s (as-cast film), 5.58 x 10^-3 cm^2 / V°s (annealed film).
4. Bandgap: 1.85 eV (PCDTBT), 1.70 eV (PCDSeBT).
5. HOMO energy level: -5.40 eV (PCDSeBT).

These are the values of material properties mentioned in the paragraph. They are related to the surface, charge transport, optical, and electronic properties of the organic semiconductors used in the study.
